title: Forrest takes swipe at BHP, Rio over customer emissions claims
text:
Ms Gaines told the meeting that institutional investors had not requested scope 3 disclosure or analysis of the consequences for Fortescue if China were to adopt emissions targets that put it on track to meet Paris climate change targets.

Mr Forrest saw red when asked if it would take a shareholder resolution similar to those faced by Rio and BHP to get Fortescue to start disclosing scope 3 emissions, saying it could face 75 resolutions but they couldn't control customer emissions.

“I really don’t appreciate being held to account as a clean company by the press statements of companies which exist on the most polluting form of energy,” he said.

No backdown on traditional owners dispute

The stinging response from Mr Forrest, who founded Fortescue and controls about 35 per cent of the stock, drew a round of applause from other shareholders, who reaped dividend and share price windfalls from the company's record-breaking performance in 2018-19.

In the case of BHP, Friends of the Earth subsidiary Market Forces relented on a shareholder resolution after BHP said it would set Paris-aligned targets for reducing scope 3 emissions and have them independently verified.

Rio announced last month that it had joined forces with China’s biggest steel maker to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

“Some of these companies have made broad statements about things they are doing – like one of them [BHP] said that they are going to have 50 per cent of the workforce female in five years’ time,” Mr Forrest said.

“That is going to create nice headlines, little sugar hits for that chief executive or some representative in the environmental community or the investor community, but that is not how we roll.

“We are not here for a headline or a sugar hit. We are here to lead by example.”

Fortescue is pushing hard to cut fossil fuel use after unveiling a deal with Alinta Energy to use a solar-gas hybrid system supported by batteries to power its Christmas Creek and Cloudbreak mines.

The company is also exploring the use of hydrogen as a power source not just in mining but for China's steel makers, although it concedes any breakthrough on that front is probably at least a decade away.

Mr Forrest also bristled when questioned about the company’s bitter legal dispute with traditional owners of land in the Pilbara where Fortescue has built its Solomon mining hub without a native title agreement.

He told a shareholder who urged Fortescue to settle a dispute with members of a community based around Roebourne in WA that he should “start employing people and make a real difference”.

Mr Forrest gave the strongest indication to date that Fortescue would seek to take the dispute to the High Court after losing a Federal Court appeal over a decision to grant the Yindjibarndi Aboriginal Corporation exclusive possession status under native title.

He said Roebourne was a community suffering from alcohol and drug abuse, "wanton misbehaviour" and that "kids don't go to school".

"That is not a community I'm to empower with tens of million of dollars of your cash," he told shareholders.

Mr Forrest also made it clear Fortescue would not make changes to non-financial targets in its bonus system despite coming close to a first strike on the remuneration report.

He said non-financial parameters were important to avoid some of the greed exposed by Kenneth Hayne in his royal commission into the banking sector.
description: The Fortescue chairman says the iron ore miner will control what it can control and not chase media "sugar hits" with claims about reducing scope 3 emissions.
